properties.Description: Distinctively different from the common oak. They can grow up to 30 metres (125 feet) tall. A wonderfully shaped tree to have outside the main entrance to the university. The leaves turn brown, russet or yellow in the Autumn but drop quite early compared to the common oak.

Known widely as the Silver Birch or the European White Birch, it grows successfully in this country alongside the Scots Pine with the Siver Birch being known as the Queen of the forest and the Scots Pine as the King. They can reach 15-25 metres (49-82 feet) Occasionally 30metres (100 feet) tall. Betula pendula is a hardy tree that appreciates dry, acid soil. It will often be the first tree to appear on wasteland. It has an open canopy which allows other plants to flourish below. In the Highlands of Scotland, wild edible mushrooms known as Chanterelles grow happily underneath them as they have a symbiotic association with the roots of the tree. Betula pendula is Finland’s national tree, and its wood is used for furniture making, plywood, veneers, skis, utensils and firewood. The sap can be tapped and drunk fresh or used for wine making.

The Nordmann Fir or Caucasian Fir grows to between 55 and 85 metres tall, (180 – 279 feet). This one has been planted as a permanent Christmas tree instead of buying a large cut one each year. We will prune this specimen as the years go by to maintain its height and shape. It is native to the Caucasus mountains at the intersection of Europe and Asia. It has been widely planted across Europe to mitigate expected forest decline caused by climate changes. It is grown widely for use as a Christmas tree because of its attractive foliage and needles that are not too sharp and do not drop readily when the tree dries out. It is also used in general construction and for making paper.

Himalayan Birch from the Western Himalayas grows to around 20 metres (66 feet) tall. Utilis means useful and the bark has been used to as paper for books, clothing, roof construction, umbrella covers, bandages and packaging (particularly butter). The wood is used for bridge construction and firewood which has caused large areas of habitat to be eliminated or reduced.

The Sycamore tree can live for 450 years reaching 35 metres (115 feet) in height. It was introduced to Great Britain by 1500 and can tolerate wind and coastal exposure. It grows very easily from seed and can become quite invasive. The timber is used for furniture, flooring, firewood and musical instruments, especially violins.

The Cedar of Lebanon is native to the Mediterranean region. Mature trees can be 40 metres (130 feet) tall. It stood intact until storms in 2010/11 caused significant damage. A younger tree has since been planted next to it. The coral was built around it to protect the public as these trees can lose branches without warning. The wood is prized and used in furniture making and construction. Cedar resin and Cedar essential oil are also highly prized extracts from the timber and cones.

Known as Gean, Wild Cherry or Bird Cherry. Native to Europe, North West Africa and Western Asia. Widely cultivated. Grows to 15-32 metres (49 – 105 feet). White flowers in early Spring as the new leaves appear. All parts of the plant are slightly toxic except for the ripe fruit which range between sweet to bitter. The fruits are eaten by a wide variety of birds and mammals. The wood is used for turning, making furniture and musical instruments. The wood can also be chipped and used to smoke food.
properties.Origin: Western Asia and Africa, Eastern Europe

properties.Description: The Grey Poplar is a hybrid between Populus alba (White Poplar) and Populus tremula (Common Aspen). A very vigourous tree, it is larger than either of its parents reaching 40 metres (130 feet) tall. It has a very extensive root system and should not be planted within 12 metres (40 feet) of buildings. Because it is tolerant of salt winds and is fast growing, it is often used as a shelterbelt tree. The bark of most of this Genus contains Salicin from which we get Aspirin which is useful as a painkiller, an anti-inflammatory and for reducing fever. Aspirin is often used to treat or prevent Heart attacks, Strokes, Chest pain and menstrual cramps.
properties.Origin: Southern and Central Europe, Asia Minor

properties.Description: Called the Lawson Cypress or Port Orford Cedar native to Oregon and N.W. California. It was discovered by collectors in Port Orford and introduced into cultivation in 1854 by collectors working for the Lawson and Son nursery in Edinburgh. Can reach up to 60 metres (200 feet) tall. This tree is approximately 20 metres (65 feet) tall. Its fragrant straight grained wood is sought after for making arrow shafts and guitars. The wood is light and has a great resistance to rot and is in high demand in Japan for making coffins.

The Grand or Giant Fir amongst other names, may be the tallest Abies species in the world, growing to 40–70 (131-229 feet) metres and exceptionally 100 metres (328 feet) tall. It was first described by Scottish Botanical explorer David Douglas in 1831 whilst collecting specimens in the Pacific Northwest. The wood is used for paper making, packing crates and construction. The inner bark was used by Plateau Indian tribes for treating colds and fever.

The European larch is a deciduous conifer native to Europe. It can grow to 55 metres (180 feet) tall. This one is approximately 24 metres (75-80 feet) high. Reports of 350 years old have been recorded. It is very cold tolerant and can survive temperatures down to –50 °C. It is thought to have been introduced and cultivated in Great Britain since 1629. The timber is used in yacht building and fencing. It is also a popular Bonsai tree.

The Western yellow pine is native to N.W. America and Canada. It is the most widely distributed Pine species in North America. The tallest one measured was 81.77 metres (268.29 feet) high. This one is about 14 metres (45 feet) tall. They are grown as ornamental trees in parks and big gardens. The seeds are eaten by Squirrels, Quail and Grouse.

Wellingtonia or giant redwood is the largest single stem tree and the largest living thing (by volume) on earth. The tallest was measured at 94.8 metres (311 feet). This one is around 23 metres (75 feet) tall. The largest measured diameter is 8.2 metres (27 feet). They can live up to 3500 years. The bark can be to 1 metre (3 feet) thick and is unusually fire resistant. They require fire to reproduce as the cones open after being exposed to heat and the seeds can germinate when excess vegetation has been burnt on the ground. The main economic uses are tourism and horticulture.

The Coast redwood is a fast growing, tall tree with attractive, reddish-brown fibrous bark. A Coast Redwood called The Hyperion tree in Redwood National Park currently boasts to be the world’s tallest living organism at over 115 metres (379 feet) high. This specimen is around 20 metres (65-70 feet) tall. They can live up to 2200 years. The timber is lightweight and resistant to decay and is used for garden furniture, planters, decking, hot-tubs and railway sleepers.

The Spanish or Sweet chestnut is native to Europe and Asia minor. It can grow to around 35 metres (115 feet) tall. These are around 15-17 metres (50-55 feet) high. They can live for up to 2000 years. The nuts are edible and traditionally roasted then dipped in salt. Wood use includes furniture making and roof beams.
The Noble fir can reach 90 metres (295 feet) high. This fine specamin has a poker straight trunk. They make popular Christmas trees and the wood is used in construction and paper making.

Western Hemlock is an elegant N.W. American tree growing up to 82metres (270 feet) tall. They have a distinctive drooping lead shoot. Some trees of the  species have been known to reach 1200 years old. They are cultivated as ornamental trees in large gardens. The bark serves as a source of  tannin for tanning.

The Norway maple can live up to 250 years and grow up to 30 metres (100 feet) high. This young specimen was planted to commemorate the 40th anniversary of Riccarton Estate being gifted to Heriot-Watt University (more information on commemorative stone). The wood is used in furniture making, flooring and musical instruments. Many Stradivarius violins were thought to be made from Norway maple.

A Coast Redwood called The Hyperion tree in Redwood National Park currently boasts to be the world’s tallest living organism at over 115 metres (379 feet) high. This specimen is around 20 metres (65-70 feet) tall. They can live up to 2200 years. The timber is lightweight and resistant to decay and is used for garden furniture, planters, decking, hot-tubs and railway sleepers.

Wellingtonia or giant redwood is the largest single stem tree and the largest living thing (by volume) on earth. The tallest was measured at 94.8 metres (311 feet). This one is around 23 metres (75 feet) tall. The largest measured diameter is 8.2 metres (27 feet). They can live up to 3500 years. The bark can be up to 1 metre (3 feet) thick and is unusually fire resistant. They require fire to reproduce as the cones open after being exposed to heat and the seeds can germinate when excess vegetation has been burnt on the ground. The main economic uses are tourism and horticulture.

Sweet chesnut can grow to around 35 metres (115 feet) tall. These are around 15-17 metres (50-55 feet) high. They can live for 2000 years. The nuts are edible and traditionally roasted then dipped in salt. Wood use includes furniture making and roof beams. These are a group of trees that originated from the Riccarton Sweet Chestnut which was over 250 years old. The original tree died back leaving peripheral shoots.

Western Red Cedar is a large tree growing up to 75 metres (245 feet) tall. This specimen is approximately 24 metres (80 feet) tall. Note how it has a layered branch from the mother plant which has created another tree. The oldest verified specimen was recorded at 1460 years old. Its wood is used for a variety of things including lightweight sailing boats and kayaks, posts, guitars and beehive frames. Mature trees have a natural fungicide called Thujaplicin which prevents the wood from rotting up to 100 years after being felled. The bark can be used for making mats, ropes, clothing and other soft goods.
The Yellow Buckeye Chestnut can reach 47 metres (154 feet) in height. It is grown as an ornamental tree for its yellow flowers and Autumn colour.

The Douglas fir is a native of N.W. America. They have been known to live for over 1000 years and the tallest on record was measured in Whatcom County, N. America in 1897 at an incredible 142 metres (465 feet) tall. The Douglas fir is the tallest tree in Britain with a specimen near Inverness standing at over 66 metres (217 feet) tall. Research shows they could reach 476 feet tall at which point water supply would fail!  The timber is used in many industries including construction, marine structures and railways. They are also popular as Christmas trees and are grown ornamentally in parks and gardens.

The Sawara Cypress is native to Japan and grows to a height of 35-50 metres (115-164 feet). Pisifera translating from Latin as pea-bearing, referring to the small round green cones. It is grown for its timber in Japan for building palaces, temples, shrines, baths and coffins.

The Mountain Hemlock is native to the North West coast of North America. Mertensiana refers to the German Botanist Karl Heinrich Mertens who collected specimens as a member of a Russian expedition in 1826-1829. A slow grower, it grows up to 20-40 metres (66-131 feet) tall, sometimes attaining 800 years in age. The cones range from dark purple to red-brown and the bark is thin, grey and square-cracked or furrowed. It is planted as a specimen tree in gardens in Northern Great Britain.

Prunus serrula Tibetica, Tibetan Cherry is a small fast growing tree is grown for its mahogany/brown peeling bark which is smooth and polished in appearance. The small white flowers appear in Spring along with narrow, dark green leaves. This lovely tree provides great interest in a garden throughout the Winter. It grows to a height of 6-8m and is a great tree for all gardens as well as parks. Grows in all well drained, moist soils in full sun or partial shade, avoid waterlogged areas.

The Common Beech growing up to 25-35 metres (82-115 feet), exceptionally 50 metres (160 feet) tall. It reaches 300-400 years old. It also makes a very good hedging plant as it doesn’t lose its leaves in winter making it an effective screen. It produces seed from 10 years old and likes a humid atmosphere and well-drained soil. The wood is used for furniture, worktops, flooring and staircases. It is also considered to be one of the best firewoods. The nuts are eaten by humans and animals but can be slightly toxic to humans if eaten in large quantities. The nuts were pressed to produce oil in the 19th century and used in cooking and lamps.

The common ash is a member of the olive family and can grow to 43 metres (141 feet) tall. This superb example was around 30 metres (100 feet) high but recently had to be reduced when a large split was discovered in the trunk. They can live up to 250 years. The wood was traditionally used for making bows, tool handles and snooker cues. It was also used in early aircraft construction. Nowadays it is more commonly used in furniture making and flooring.
Commonly known as the monkey puzzle tree or Chilean pine. It can reach heights of 40 metres (130 feet). The seeds are edible, but the wood is seldom used because of its scarcity.

Koyama’s Spruce is named after Japanese Botanist, Mitsua Koyama. An evergreen tree growing to 25 metres (82 feet) tall. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has rated this species as “critically endangered”. This specimen was part of a consignment of trees received from the Royal Botanic Gardens Edinburgh (RBGE) as part of the International Conifer Conservation Programme (ICCP). Heriot-Watt University struck a relationship with the RBGE to help with conservation work and it allows us to obtain rare trees to add to the wide variety of species already on campus.

Endemic to coastal areas and islands off the coast of Croatia, this species is threatened in its natural habitat by over grazing, especially by feral goats. This subspecies only attains modest stature, not exceeding 15 metres (49 feet) tall mainly due to its poor environment and exposure to wind from the sea. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has rated this species as “endangered”. This specimen was part of a consignment of trees received from the Royal Botanic Gardens Edinburgh (RBGE) as part of the International Conifer Conservation Programme (ICCP). Heriot-Watt University struck a relationship with the RBGE to help with conservation work and it allows us to obtain rare trees to add to the wide variety of species already on campus.

The Scots pine is the national tree of Scotland and is native to Eurasia. It has distinctive blue/green leaves and orange/red bark which gives it a striking appearance against a clear blue sky. The tallest recorded specimen is over 46 metres (152 feet) tall. This one stands at around 20 metres (65-70 feet) high. The oldest recorded tree was 760 years old. The Scots pine helped make up the Caledonian forest of which there is only just over 1% remaining. The Scots Pine was known as the King of the forest with the Silver Birch being known as the Queen. The wood is used for pulp and timber products. Rosin and turpentine are also made from Scots pine.

The Patagonian Cypress is a Genus with a single species and is endemic to Argentina and Chile where it is globally threatened by selective logging, grazing and fire. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has rated this species as “endangered”. This specimen was part of a consignment of trees received from the Royal Botanic Gardens Edinburgh (RBGE) as part of the International Conifer Conservation Programme (ICCP). Heriot-Watt University struck a relationship with the RBGE to help with conservation work and it allows us to obtain rare trees to add to the wide variety of species already on campus.

Known as the Flaky Fir, it is native to China and Tibet. It can grow to 40 metres (120 feet) tall. Direct exploitation for timber has led to a decline in the population. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has rate this species as “vulnerable”. This specimen was part of a consignment of trees received from the Royal Botanic Gardens Edinburgh (RBGE) as part of the International Conifer Conservation Programme (ICCP). Heriot-Watt University struck a relationship with the RBGE to help with conservation work and it allows us to obtain rare trees to add to the wide variety of species already on campus.

The common oak is a long living deciduous tree native to most of Europe. They can live over 1500 years and reach heights of 40 metres (130 feet). This specimen stands at about 22 metres (70-75 feet) tall. They are ecologically important to a host of insects and other wildlife and they are a valuable food source for birds and small mammals. The wood is widely used in furniture making and flooring.

The Western yellow pine is native to N.W. America and Canada. The tallest one measured was 81.77 metres (268.29 feet) high. This one is about 23 metres (75 feet) tall. They are grown as ornamental trees in parks and big gardens.
A golden form of the common yew. This specimen stands about 7-9 metres (25-30 feet) tall.
The Irish yew is an upright plant growing up to 12 metres (40 feet) in height. It is commonly used as a hedging plant.

This tree is native to Eastern Asia. This compact oval shaped specimen is about 6 metres (20 feet) tall with attractive green foliage. The wood of Chamaecyparis is highly valued in Japan for temple construction.
The Adpressa yew or short leaved Japan Yew. Can reach upwards of 6 metres (20 feet). This is a mature example at around that height.

The Japanese Thuja, native to Southern Japan. It is a medium sized tree reaching about 20-35 metres (65-115 feet) tall. The durable, waterproof, attractively scented wood is highly prized for special building purposes, ceilings and panelling. It is also used for furniture, fanlights and clogs. It is widely planted in Japan. The IUCN status for this species is “near threatened”.

The Japanese Red Cedar is a large evergreen tree reaching 70 metres (230 feet) tall in its natural habitat. This one is the Chinese form of the species and stands 15 metres (50 feet) high. It has been known to live up to 1000 years old in the wild. The timber is very fragrant and is weather and insect resistant. Its wood is used for construction, cask making and furniture.

The Corsican Pine is native to the woodlands around the Mediterranean and can grow up to 55 metres (180 feet) tall. This specimen is approximately 20 metres (65-70 feet) tall. It has, over the years lost a number of large limbs to storm damage but still has a marvelous open crown. Its timber is used for construction, paper making and fuel.

The Wollemi pine is native to Australia and was thought to be extinct until 1994 when it was discovered to be growing in New South Wales. There is less than 100 adult plants growing in the wild. They were made available to Botanic gardens from 2006. Lowest recorded temperatures tolerated are known to be -12 C. It is not a true pine or a member of the pine family. The oldest fossil of the Wollemi tree is dated to 200 million years ago. It can reach 40 metres (130 feet) tall. This specimen is 2 metres (6 feet) tall and was planted in 2010 to recognise Sir William Gibson-Craig’s contribution to Edinburgh plant collection.

Known as the Tulip Tree or White Wood. Native to N.E. America. Can reach 50 metres (165 feet) tall in its natural habitat. This specimen is around 12-14 metres (40-45 feet) tall. The flowers are pale green or yellow. Foliage turns a super golden yellow colour in Autumn. The tulip tree is a major honey plant in Eastern North America due to the large amounts of nectar it produces. The wood is widely used in construction and organ making.

The Grand or Giant Fir amongst other names, may be the tallest Abies species in the world, growing to 40–70 (131-229 feet) metres and exceptionally 100 metres (328 feet) tall. It was first described by Scottish Botanical explorer David Douglas in 1831 whilst collecting specimens in the Pacific Northwest. The wood is used for paper making, packing crates and construction. The inner bark was used by Plateau Indian tribes for treating colds and fever.

Copper beech is an attractive large tree growing up to 42 metres (140 feet) tall. This specimen is approximately 20-22 metres (65-75 feet) tall. These trees can live up to 300 years. The root system is shallow with large roots spreading out in all directions. Its wood is used for furniture making, flooring and staircases. The nuts are an important food source for birds and rodents.

The Dragon’s claw or Corkscrew Willow is native to Northern China. It can reach 20-25 metres (66-88 feet) tall. It grows well in moderately fertile soil in full sun. Fast growing, it reaches maturity in 20-50 years. Propagate by softwood cuttings in early Summer or hardwood cuttings in Winter. Grown as a shelterbelt plant, it is important around the Oases of the Gobi desert, protecting agricultural land from desert winds.

The Atlas Cedar is native to the Atlas mountains of Morocco. It can reach up to 40 metres (130 feet) high. This one is around 12-14 metres (40-45 feet) tall. It lost a large limb when younger but has recovered its shape well. They have attractive blue/green tight knit needles. More tolerant of hot, dry conditions than most conifers. They are commonly grown in cultivation as an ornamental tree and grown in France for timber.
